# Samuel Prescott

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

For other people named Samuel Prescott, see [Samuel Prescott
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Samuel_Prescott_\(disambiguation\) "Samuel Prescott
\(disambiguation\)").

Samuel Prescott  
---  
Born|  August 19, 1751  
[Concord, Massachusetts](/wiki/Concord,_Massachusetts "Concord,
Massachusetts"), [British America](/wiki/British_America "British America")  
Died|  between November 23, 1776 and December 26, 1777  
Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada  
Occupation|  Surgeon, Express courier  
  
**Samuel Prescott** (August 19, 1751 – c. 1777) was a
[Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts")
[Patriot](/wiki/Patriot_\(American_Revolution\) "Patriot \(American
Revolution\)") during the [American Revolutionary
War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"). He is
best remembered for his role in [Paul Revere](/wiki/Paul_Revere "Paul
Revere")'s "midnight ride" to warn the townspeople of
[Concord](/wiki/Concord,_Massachusetts "Concord, Massachusetts") of the
impending British army move to capture guns and gunpowder kept there at the
beginning of the American Revolution. He was the only participant in the ride
to reach Concord.[1]

## Contents

  * 1 Early life
  * 2 The Ride
  * 3 Prescott's life following "The Ride"
  * 4 Legacy
  * 5 See also
  * 6 Notes
  * 7 Sources

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Prescott&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Jonathan_Prescott%2C_Chester%2C_Nova_Scotia.png/220px-
Jonathan_Prescott%2C_Chester%2C_Nova_Scotia.png)](/wiki/File:Jonathan_Prescott,_Chester,_Nova_Scotia.png)

[](/wiki/File:Jonathan_Prescott,_Chester,_Nova_Scotia.png "Enlarge")

Samuel Prescott's uncle [Jonathan
Prescott](/wiki/Jonathan_Prescott_\(military_officer\) "Jonathan Prescott
\(military officer\)")

Dr. Samuel Prescott was born August 19, 1751. He lived in colonial [Concord,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Concord,_Massachusetts "Concord, Massachusetts"), among
his large extended family. (His uncle was [Jonathan
Prescott](/wiki/Jonathan_Prescott_\(military_officer\) "Jonathan Prescott
\(military officer\)").) Much of this history was probably passed on to the
family by his grand uncle Samuel Prescott, who knew many of the early
Prescotts, and was even old enough to remember the first ancestor of the
Concord branch of the family, John Prescott,[2] founder of [Lancaster,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Lancaster,_Massachusetts "Lancaster, Massachusetts").[3]
Indeed, the Prescotts and their extended family played an important and often
heroic role in colonial history. These include settling Concord, fighting in
colonial wars, and negotiating for the ransom of [Mary
Rowlandson](/wiki/Mary_Rowlandson "Mary Rowlandson").[4]

Prescott followed in the footsteps of his older brother Benjamin and
apprenticed under his father, Abel Prescott, for about seven years. He appears
to have kept an extremely low profile during pre-revolutionary times as well
as afterward, as best can be attained. He did open a practice in Concord, just
before or after which time he began to court Lydia Mulliken, daughter of a
well-respected Lexington clockmaker who had died in 1767.[5]

During the latter part of his [apprenticeship](/wiki/Apprenticeship
"Apprenticeship") or shortly after he began his medical practice, he became an
active member in the [patriot movement](/wiki/Patriot_\(American_Revolution\)
"Patriot \(American Revolution\)"). There is strong circumstantial evidence
that he was an express courier for the [Sons of Liberty](/wiki/Sons_of_Liberty
"Sons of Liberty") and the [Committees of
Correspondence](/wiki/Committees_of_Correspondence "Committees of
Correspondence"), and that he was an important liaison between the Concord
Defense Committee and [John Hancock](/wiki/John_Hancock "John Hancock") and
other leaders of the patriots.[6]

## The Ride[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Prescott&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: The Ride")]

On the evening of April 18, 1775, [Paul Revere](/wiki/Paul_Revere "Paul
Revere") and [William Dawes](/wiki/William_Dawes "William Dawes") were
dispatched by [Joseph Warren](/wiki/Joseph_Warren "Joseph Warren") to warn the
countryside that the British were coming. Prescott was in Lexington at the
time to visit with his fiancée, Lydia Mulliken.[7] He was also there to report
on Concord's readiness, its status in hiding supplies and munitions from the
British, and its success in moving cannon to Groton lest it fall into British
hands.[8] The British wanted the military stores at Concord and had hoped to
capture [Samuel Adams](/wiki/Samuel_Adams "Samuel Adams") and John Hancock in
the process.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

When Prescott left Lexington, it was about 1 a.m. the next morning, April 19.
On his way back to Concord he met Paul Revere and William Dawes, who had just
left Lexington shortly before him and were also on their way to Concord—to
warn the town that the Redcoats were on the march.[9]

When the three continued on to Hartwell's tavern in the lower bounds of
Lincoln, they were cut off by four British horseman who were part of a larger
scouting party sent out the preceding evening. Revere was captured but both
Prescott and Dawes succeeded in making a run for it. Prescott did so with a
show of artful horsemanship and knowledge of the forest. Finally losing his
pursuers, he circled about and headed quickly to Concord, carrying Revere's
warning to his townsmen.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Dawes also escaped from his pursuers, but it was after a close chase, a
frantic ruse on his part, and a bit of luck. Once he was safe, he considered
circling around the patrol and racing on to Concord much as Prescott had, but
he heard the Concord town house bell and knew Prescott had made it there, and
so he continued on his special mission, for he was only assigned to accompany
Revere to Concord.[10] Prescott, meanwhile, continued west to warn Acton,
Massachusetts while his brother [Abel Prescott, Jr.](/wiki/Abel_Prescott,_Jr.
"Abel Prescott, Jr.") rode south to warn
[Sudbury](/wiki/Sudbury,_Massachusetts "Sudbury, Massachusetts") and
[Framingham](/wiki/Framingham,_Massachusetts "Framingham, Massachusetts"). By
this time, countless riders were also dispatched from other towns to spread
the warning—while bells and cannon were rung or fired to punctuate the danger
at hand.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Because of the "midnight" rides of Revere, Dawes, Prescott, and many other
expresses (couriers), [minutemen](/wiki/Minutemen "Minutemen") and
[militia](/wiki/Militia "Militia") everywhere were on the ready, many marching
to Concord to effectively engage the British Army at the Battles of Lexington
and Concord. Prescott was there to witness the [Battle of
Concord](/wiki/Battle_of_Concord "Battle of Concord"), then tried to beat the
British back to Lexington to see Lydia Mulliken and her family and to help
with the wounded.[11] He remained at Lexington as a volunteer surgeon for
about two weeks, then seems to have disappeared into the war.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Concord_Expedition_and_Patriot_Messengers.jpg/800px-
Concord_Expedition_and_Patriot_Messengers.jpg)](/wiki/File:Concord_Expedition_and_Patriot_Messengers.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Concord_Expedition_and_Patriot_Messengers.jpg "Enlarge")

A [National Park Service](/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service")
map showing the route of the initial
[Patriot](/wiki/Patriot_\(American_Revolution\) "Patriot \(American
Revolution\)") messengers including Prescott (purple trail)

## Prescott's life following "The
Ride"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Prescott&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Prescott's life following "The Ride"")]

There is evidence that Prescott went on to serve as a surgeon in the
[Continental Army](/wiki/Continental_Army "Continental Army"), a tradition
that he joined the crew of a New England [privateer](/wiki/Privateer
"Privateer"), and a report that he was in prison in [Halifax, Nova
Scotia](/wiki/City_of_Halifax "City of Halifax"), where he may have died
between November 23, 1776 and December 26 (1777?).[12] There is also
circumstantial evidence that he served in some medical support capacity out of
[Fort Ticonderoga](/wiki/Fort_Ticonderoga "Fort Ticonderoga") during the
invasion attempts against Canada and until about the time of [Benedict
Arnold](/wiki/Benedict_Arnold "Benedict Arnold")'s failed attempts against
[Sir Guy Carleton](/wiki/Sir_Guy_Carleton "Sir Guy Carleton") on [Lake
Champlain](/wiki/Lake_Champlain "Lake Champlain").[13]

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Prescott&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Legacy")]

Prescott's ride is re-enacted every [Patriots' Day](/wiki/Patriots%27_Day
"Patriots' Day") eve (observed) in the Town of Acton. The re-enactment begins
in East Acton, continues through Acton Center, and ends at Liberty Tree Farm,
where once was the home of a minuteman named Simon Hunt. The distance is
approximately five miles (8 km).

There are also re-enactments on Patriots' Day (usually the third Monday of
April) of the rides of William Dawes and Paul Revere, to commemorate the
famous "midnight" ride that began in the evening hours of April 18 and
continued on April 19.

Prescott's ride is re-enacted every year at midnight April 18–19 at Concord's
First Parish Church. The re-enactment is preceded by a Patriots' Ball. The
Minute Men march with fife and drum leading the attendees from the armory to
the church. The Captain of the Concord Minute Men reads a message handed him
by "Prescott" on horseback.

A memorial plaque to Prescott is at his former home in Concord,
Massachusetts.[14]

## See also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Prescott&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: See also")]

  * _[Liberty's Kids](/wiki/Liberty%27s_Kids "Liberty's Kids")_

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Prescott&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Notes")]

  2. **Jump up ^** Caes, 49–50
  3. **Jump up ^** Marvin, 38–47
  4. **Jump up ^** Caes, 34, wherein regarding Rowlandson the reference is to John Hoar, father of the second wife of Capt. Jonathan Prescott (d. 1721). Captain Jonathan was Samuel Prescott's great grandfather.
  5. **Jump up ^** ["The Tale of Two Families Joined by Love, Shattered by War"](https://web.archive.org/web/20090724051850/http://www.concordma.com/magazine/julaug01/samuelprescott.html). _Concord Magazine_. D. Michael Ryan. Archived from [the original](http://www.concordma.com/magazine/julaug01/samuelprescott.html) on 24 July 2009. Retrieved 24 July 2009.
  6. **Jump up ^** Caes, 206
  7. **Jump up ^** Prescott, 66
  8. **Jump up ^** Wheildon, 7
  9. **Jump up ^** Dawes, 89, but this is taken, as cited in his book, from Revere's deposition for Reverend Jerry Belknap, founder of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Revere actually produced three versions of the deposition, two in 1775 and one in 1798, but they are not contradictory though they are of varying lengths.
  10. **Jump up ^** Dawes, 119
  11. **Jump up ^** Caes, 248–253
  12. **Jump up ^** There is only hearsay of the privateering, and Caes provides other alternatives, beginning with the Battles of Breed's and Bunker Hills at which he lists a number of Samuel's relatives (some through marriage) who fought there.
  13. **Jump up ^** Speculations of which appear in _Legend_
  14. **Jump up ^** [Samuel Prescott](https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/7752485) at [Find a Grave](/wiki/Find_a_Grave "Find a Grave")

"Edit section: Sources")]

qa.question: who warned concord that the british were coming

m.062pq1_6.Query Analysis: The query asks about the person who warned Concord that the British were coming, specifically during the events leading up to the Battles of Lexington and Concord.
m.062pq1_6.Answer Analysis: The answer is Samuel Prescott, indicating he was the person who warned Concord about the approaching British forces.
m.062pq1_6.Document Content Analysis: The document describes the military conflicts that started with the Battles of Lexington and Concord on April 19, 1775, detailing the actions of militias against the British forces. It mentions the Siege of Boston, the Battle of Bunker Hill, and George Washington taking command of the militia. The document also provides descriptions of the Boston campaign in different languages.
m.062pq1_6.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Concord', 'British', and the context of the Battles of Lexington and Concord.
m.062pq1_6.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not mention 'Samuel Prescott'.
m.062pq1_6.Key Information Matching: The document provides context about the Battles of Lexington and Concord, which are directly related to the query, but it does not mention the specific individual who warned Concord.
m.062pq1_6.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not mention Samuel Prescott or anyone else who warned Concord.
m.062pq1_6.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides historical context about the events surrounding the Battles of Lexington and Concord, which are relevant to understanding the broader situation in which the warning would have occurred.
m.062pq1_6.Explanation: The document is partially relevant as it provides context about the Battles of Lexington and Concord, which are directly related to the query. However, it lacks the specific information about who warned Concord, making it unable to directly answer the query but still useful for understanding the historical background.

triviaqa_15607_11.Query Analysis: The query asks for the identity of the person who warned Concord that the British were coming during the American Revolutionary period.
triviaqa_15607_11.Answer Analysis: The answer identifies Samuel Prescott as the person who warned Concord.
triviaqa_15607_11.Document Content Analysis: The document describes the events leading up to the American Revolution, specifically the warning of the British advance. It mentions a series of horseback riders, including Paul Revere, William Dawes, and Dr. Samuel Prescott, who warned the countryside. The document also includes an account by Paul Revere about their journey and encounter with British officers.
triviaqa_15607_11.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document includes the keywords 'warned', 'Concord', and 'British'.
triviaqa_15607_11.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Dr. Samuel Prescott', which matches the answer.
triviaqa_15607_11.Key Information Matching: The document directly mentions Dr. Samuel Prescott as one of the riders who warned the countryside, including Concord, about the British advance.
triviaqa_15607_11.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document explicitly states that Dr. Samuel Prescott warned Concord.
triviaqa_15607_11.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides context about the warning system and the roles of other riders like Paul Revere and William Dawes.
triviaqa_15607_11.Explanation: The document is directly relevant to the query as it explicitly mentions Dr. Samuel Prescott as one of the riders who warned Concord. It provides substantial context about the events and the warning process, enhancing understanding of the query's topic.

m.062pq1_5.Query Analysis: The query asks about the person who warned Concord that the British were coming, specifically during the American Revolutionary War.
m.062pq1_5.Answer Analysis: The answer is Samuel Prescott, indicating he was the person who warned Concord about the approaching British forces.
m.062pq1_5.Document Content Analysis: The document describes the Boston campaign, which was the opening campaign of the American Revolutionary War. It mentions the Battles of Lexington and Concord on April 19, 1775, where militias attempted to stop the British from seizing military stores in Concord, Massachusetts. The document also discusses the Siege of Boston and the Battle of Bunker Hill.
m.062pq1_5.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Concord' and 'British', which are directly related to the query.
m.062pq1_5.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not mention 'Samuel Prescott'.
m.062pq1_5.Key Information Matching: The document provides context about the Battles of Lexington and Concord, which are relevant to the timeframe and location mentioned in the query, but it does not specify who warned Concord.
